article.title: Active Learning Worksheet
article.subtitle: Section 3.1 - Introduction to the Family of Quadratic Functions

abstract.p: This worksheet is meant to be used in class. You should be working in groups or individually depending on the instructions from your teacher.
You can submit answers any number of times.

Remember that the point is that you learn from your mistakes and with the help of your peers, so make sure you reflect on incorrect answers and try again with your new understanding. If you can't figure it out, ask your teacher, or bring up your strategy in a whole class discussion. This will allow you to get as much out of the activity.

section.title: Instructions
section.p: (this text is repeated from the abstract in the Front Matter - the most appropriate location should be determined)
This worksheet is meant to be used in class. You should be working in groups or individually depending on the instructions from your teacher.
You can submit answers any number of times.

Remember that the point is that you learn from your mistakes and with the help of your peers, so make sure you reflect on incorrect answers and try again with your new understanding. If you can't figure it out, ask your teacher, or bring up your strategy in a whole class discussion. This will allow you to get as much out of the activity.

section.title: Goals
section.p: After completing your work on this section, you should be able to:

ul.li: Find the zeros of a quadratic function by factoring or using the quadratic formula.
Determine the concavity of the graph of a quadratic function from a formula.
Find the formula of a quadratic function given its zeros and an additional point on the graph.
Recognize the standard and factored forms of a quadratic function.

section.p: Make sure you have this goals in mind as you are working on the problems in this worksheet.

ul.li: The graph of a quadratic function is a parabola.

li.p:
Factored form: y = a (x-r)(x-s)
zeros: r and s

ul.li: Concavity from the equation: a\gt 0 means concave up, a\lt 0 means concave down.

introduction.p: SOME Introductory TEXT HERE?

subsection.title: Identifying parameters
subsection.p: This section gives you practice on identifying the parameters in the different "common" forms one writes quadratic functions.

introduction.p: This example is taken form the PreTeXt sample file. Try giving the coefficients without the correct sign.

statement.p: Consider the quadratic equation given by = 0\text{.} Identify the coefficients for the quadratic equation using the standard form.

solution.p: Take the coefficient of x^2 for the value of a, the coefficient of x for b, and the constant for c. In this case, they are a = , b = , c = .

introduction.p: Try giving k with wrong sign to see how feedback works.

statement.p: Write y= ( x-4)(4-20x) in the form y=k(x-r)(x-s) and give the values of k,r,s.

webwork.hint: What do you need to factor out of x-4 so that the coefficient of x becomes 1? In other words, what values of a and b allow you to write x-4=a(x-b)?

solution.p: Note that the order of r and s does not matter.

conclusion.p: Try swapping your answers for r and s! What do you notice?

introduction.p: SOME Introductory TEXT HERE?

subsection.title: Finding zeros practice
subsection.p: In the following problems find the zeros (if any) of the function algebraically.

introduction.p: Introductory text for problem if needed.

statement.p: Find the zeros (if any) of the function algebraically. Enter NONE in the response fields below if there are no zeros. y=(-x)(- x)
Give exact answers, or round to three decimal places.
Smallest zero (if any) at x=
Largest zero (if any) at x=

webwork.hint: Use the fact that a b=0 exactly when a=0 or b=0.

solution.p:
Setting the factors equal to zero, we have
-x\amp =\amp 0 x\amp =\amp ,
and
- x\amp =\amp 0 x\amp =\amp /,
so the zeros are x=,/.

statement.p: Find the zeros (if any) of the function algebraically. Enter NONE in the response field below if there are no zeros. y= x^2+ x+1
Separate answers with commas. Round your answers to three decimal places.
Zeros at x=

hint.p: Try to factor the equation, or use the quadratic formula.

solution.p:
To find the zeros, we solve the equation 0 = x^2+ x+1. We see that this is factorable, as follows:
y \amp =\amp ( x+1)( x+1) y \amp =\amp ( x+1)^2.
Therefore, there is only one zero at x=-\frac{1}{}.

statement.p: Find the zeros (if any) of the function algebraically. Enter NONE in the response field below if there are no zeros. y= x^2+55x+
Separate answers with commas. Round your answers to three decimal places.
Zeros at x=

hint.p: To find the zeros one must solve the equation 0= x^2+55x+ . Try to factor the expression or use the quadratic formula.

solution.p: Since \sqrt{- } is undefined, there are no zeros.

statement.p: Find the zeros (if any) of the function algebraically. Enter NONE in the response field below if there are no zeros. Q(r)= r^2- r-
Separate answers with commas. Round your answers to three decimal places.
Zeros at r=

hint.p: Try to factor Q(r) or use the quadratic formula.

solution.p: Therefore r=( + )/= and r=( - )/=-. The zeros of Q(r) are r= and r=-.

subsection.title: First set Wrap-up
subsection.p: Discuss these questions before moving on.

ul.li: How many different ways have you learned for finding the zeros of a quadratic function? What is the advantage of each method?
How many zeros can a quadratic function have?

section.title: Second set - How do the graphs look like?

introduction.p: How do the graphs look like?

subsection.title: Concavity from the formula
subsection.p: In the following problems, is the graph of the quadratic function concave up or concave down?

introduction.p: Introductory text for problem if needed.

statement.p: Is the graph of the quadratic function concave up or concave down?

webwork.hint: Will the coefficient of x^2 be positive or negative if you expand completely?

solution.p: Without fully multiplying out, we can see that the coefficient of x^2 is , so this function has a graph which is .

introduction.p: To give extra practice with another seed.

webwork.hint: Will the coefficient of x^2 be positive or negative if you expand completely?

solution.p: Without fully multiplying out, we can see that the coefficient of x^2 is , so this function has a graph which is concave down.

subsection.title: Formula from its graph
subsection.p: In the following problems, find a formula for the parabola.

introduction.p: This problem has not been randomized yet.

statement.p: Find a formula for the parabola.

hint.p: There is a relationship between the x-intercepts of the parabola and the factors in the formula.

solution.p:
We know there are zeros at x=- and x=, so we use the factored form: y=a(x+)(x-) and solve for a. At x=0, we have
\amp=\amp a(0+)(0-) \amp=\amp - a -\frac{}{} \amp=\amp a.
Thus, y=-\frac{}{}(x+)(x-) or y = -\frac{}{} x^2-\frac{}{}x +.

introduction.p: This problem has not been randomized yet.

statement.p: Find a formula for the parabola.

hint.p: Which of the ways to write the equation of a parabola allows you to see the zeros more easily?

solution.p:
We know there are zeros at x=- and x=, so we use the factored form: y=a(x+)(x-) and solve for a. At x=0, we have
\amp=\amp a(0+)(0-) \amp=\amp - a -\frac{}{} \amp=\amp a.
Thus, y=-\frac{}{}(x+)(x-) or y = -\frac{}{} x^2-\frac{}{}x +.

introduction.p: This problem is based on 3-1pw36, but it does not give the y-intercept, so there are multiple correct answers.

statement.p: Find at leas two different formulas for the parabola.

hint.p: Which of the ways to write the equation of a parabola allows you to see the zeros more easily?

solution.p:
We know there are zeros at x=- and x=, so we use the factored form: y=a(x+)(x-) and solve for a. At x=0, we have
\amp=\amp a(0+)(0-) \amp=\amp - a -\frac{}{} \amp=\amp a.
Thus, y=-\frac{}{}(x+)(x-) or y = -\frac{}{} x^2-\frac{}{}x +.

introduction.p: Text.

statement.p: Find a formula for the quadratic function whose graph has a y-intercept of y= and only one zero at x=-.

hint.p: What do you know about the vertex of the parabola if there is only one zero at x=-? Use this, and the y-intercept, to find the leading coefficient.

solution.p:
There is one zero at x=-, so by symmetry the vertex is (-,0). We have y=a(x+)^2. Solving for a, we have
a(0+)^2\amp =\amp a\amp =\amp a \amp =\amp \frac{ }{},
so y=.

introduction.p: Text.

statement.p: Find a formula for the quadratic function whose graph has a y-intercept of y= and x-intercepts at x= ,.

hint.p: Use the fact that there is a relationship between the x-intercepts and the zeros of a function.

solution.p:
The zeros are x= ,, so y=a(x- )(x- ). Solving for a, we have
a(0- )(0- )\amp =\amp a\amp =\amp a\amp =\amp \frac{ }{},
so y= .

introduction.p: Text.

statement.p: Using the factored form, find the formula for the parabola whose zeros are x=- and x= , and which passes through the point (,).

hint.p: There is a relationship between the zeros of the parabola and the factors in the formula.

solution.p: Since the parabola has x-intercepts at x=- and x= , its formula is: y=a(x+ )(x- ). The coordinates (, ) must satisfy the equation, so =a(+ )(- ). Solving for a gives a=\frac{}{}. The formula is: y=\frac{}{} (x+ )(x- ).

subsection.title: Formula from its graph - extra practice
subsection.p: In the following problems, find a formula for the parabola.

introduction.p: This problem has not been randomized yet.

statement.p: Find a formula for the parabola.

hint.p: There is a relationship between the x-intercepts of the parabola and the factors in the formula.

solution.p:
We know there are zeros at x=- and x=, so we use the factored form: y=a(x+)(x-) and solve for a. At x=0, we have
\amp=\amp a(0+)(0-) \amp=\amp - a -\frac{}{} \amp=\amp a.
Thus, y=-\frac{}{}(x+)(x-) or y = -\frac{}{} x^2-\frac{}{}x +.

introduction.p: This problem has not been randomized yet.

We know there are zeros at x=- and x=, so we use the factored form: y=a(x+)(x-) and solve for a. At x=0, we have
\amp=\amp a(0+)(0-) \amp=\amp - a -\frac{}{} \amp=\amp a.
Thus, y=-\frac{}{}(x+)(x-) or y = -\frac{}{} x^2-\frac{}{}x +.

introduction.p: This problem is based on 3-1pw36, but it does not give the y-intercept, so there are multiple correct answers.

statement.p: Find at leas two different formulas for the parabola.

hint.p: Which of the ways to write the equation of a parabola allows you to see the zeros more easily?

solution.p:
We know there are zeros at x=- and x=, so we use the factored form: y=a(x+)(x-) and solve for a. At x=0, we have
\amp=\amp a(0+)(0-) \amp=\amp - a -\frac{}{} \amp=\amp a.
Thus, y=-\frac{}{}(x+)(x-) or y = -\frac{}{} x^2-\frac{}{}x +.

introduction.p: Text.

statement.p: Find a formula for the quadratic function whose graph has a y-intercept of y= and only one zero at x=-.

hint.p: What do you know about the vertex of the parabola if there is only one zero at x=-? Use this, and the y-intercept, to find the leading coefficient.

solution.p:
There is one zero at x=-, so by symmetry the vertex is (-,0). We have y=a(x+)^2. Solving for a, we have
a(0+)^2\amp =\amp a\amp =\amp a \amp =\amp \frac{ }{},
so y=.

introduction.p: Text.

statement.p: Find a formula for the quadratic function whose graph has a y-intercept of y= and x-intercepts at x= ,.

hint.p: Use the fact that there is a relationship between the x-intercepts and the zeros of a function.

solution.p:
The zeros are x= ,, so y=a(x- )(x- ). Solving for a, we have
a(0- )(0- )\amp =\amp a\amp =\amp a\amp =\amp \frac{ }{},
so y= .

introduction.p: Text.

statement.p: Using the factored form, find the formula for the parabola whose zeros are x=- and x= , and which passes through the point (,).

hint.p: There is a relationship between the zeros of the parabola and the factors in the formula.

solution.p: Since the parabola has x-intercepts at x=- and x= , its formula is: y=a(x+ )(x- ). The coordinates (, ) must satisfy the equation, so =a(+ )(- ). Solving for a gives a=\frac{}{}. The formula is: y=\frac{}{} (x+ )(x- ).

subsection.title: Second set Wrap-up
subsection.p: Discuss these questions before moving on.

ul.li: Is it possible for two different quadratic functions to have the same zeros? If so, give specific examples.
Given the formula of a quadratic function in standard form, how do you determine the concavity of its graph? What if it is given in factored form?
How many different ways have you learned for finding the zeros of a quadratic function? What is the advantage of each method?
How many zeros can a quadratic function have?
Is it possible for two different quadratic functions to have the same zeros? If so, give specific examples.
Given the formula of a quadratic function in standard form, how do you determine the concavity of its graph? What if it is given in factored form?
What information is needed to write the formula of a quadratic function in factored form?
